greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle built from m-primes as columns.
comment: m-primes (also called m-almost primes) are the numbers which have precisely m prime factors counting multiple factors. 1 is included as 0-prime.
The number N>=1 appears in column nr. m = A001222(N).
formula: For n>=m>=1: a(n, m)= (n-m+1)-th member in the strictly monotonically increasing sequence of numbers N satisfying: N=product(p(k)^(e_k), k=1..) with p(k) := A000040(k) (k-th prime) such that sum(e_k, k=1..) = m, where the e_k are nonnegative. if m=0 : a(n, 0)=1 if n=0 else 0. If n<m then a(n, m)=0.
mathematica: With[{nn = 11}, Function[s, Function[t, Table[Function[m, If[m == 1, Boole[k == 1], t[[m, k]]]][n - k + 1], {n, nn}, {k, n, 1, -1}]]@ Map[Position[s, #][[All, 1]] &, Range[0, nn]]]@ PrimeOmega@ Range[2^nn]] (* or *)

a = {1}; Do[Block[{r = {Prime@ n}}, Do[AppendTo[r, SelectFirst[ Range[a[[-(n - i)]] + 1, 2^n], PrimeOmega@ # == i &]], {i, 2, n - 1}]; a = Join[a, {0}, If[n == 1, {}, r], {2^n}]], {n, 11}]; a (* _Michael De Vlieger_, May 24 2017 *)
xref: The column sequences (without leading zeros) are: A000007, A000040 (primes), A001358, A014612-4, A046306, A046308, A046310, A046312, A046314, A069272-A069281 for m=0..20, respectively.
A078840 is this table with the zeros omitted.
results.author: _Wolfdieter Lang_, Feb 13 2004
